newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil's Paranagua hopes strike won't hit exports.
newsitem.headline: Brazil's Paranagua hopes strike won't hit exports.

text.p: Officials of the key Brazilian port of Paranagua hope that even if a strike by stevedores at Santos port extends to the national level this week, grain loading could continue at the export terminal.
"The strike could well extend to Paranagua because stevedores are very united," a spokeswoman said.
"But in function of the relationship the port currently has with stevedores...I don't think there will be a global action inside Paranagua port," she added.

Stevedores at Santos began a strike as of 0700 local/1000 GMT over a ruling which allows company workers from steel mill Companhia Siderurgica Paulista (Cosipa) to operate Cosipa's private terminal at the port.
The strike is scheduled to last 48 hours and could spread to national level on Friday if the dispute is not resolved, the stevedores' union said.
The Paranagua spokeswoman said the port authority there would ask stevedores that operations be maintained at the export terminal where loading of grains is mostly automated.
"I don't know how they would react to the superintendent's request that at least the export corridor not stop operating," she said.
But since the port authority had mediated in a recent strike by stevedores over pay, relations between the two sides were healthy, she said.
Loading of grains at Paranagua has historically not been affected by strikes, but was halted during a protest over pay in early March.
